awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Phylogeographic Investigation of Aedes aegypti
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the geographic range and movement of the mosquito vector Aedes aegypti in arid desert environments. Arid environments are of increasing attention for mosquito control as Ae. aegypti has recently and rapidly expanded into these arid environments. Ae. aegypti mosquitoes transmit dengue, yellow fever, Zika, and chikungunya viruses. This project sequences and analyzes the entire mitochondrial genome using phylogenetic techniques and couples these data with a spatially explicit analysis of phylogenetic patterns over two seasons. This analysis contributes to an understanding of which local conditions result in source populations and high individual counts. A more complete understanding of the underlying geographic distribution and movement of Ae. aegypti in arid desert environments is beneficial to vector control and public health efforts as this mosquito continues to expand its range and outbreaks of disease occur. This understanding supports public health interventions to be targeted efficiently and effectively to those at greatest risk by establishing a “range of risk” for Ae. aegypti-borne diseases.

The objective of this project is to utilize whole mitochondrial genome sequencing of mosquito pools collected over two mosquito seasons to better understand the movement of the vector within this area, as well as any potential source locations of the mosquito population. Researchers will work with public health officials to procure geo-located mosquito samples from 2019 and 2020. Data will be sequenced and analyzed to produce the entire mitochondrial genome using various phylogenetic and phylogeographic techniques. This project develops an understanding of the geographic distribution and movement of Ae. aegypti and identifies potential source locations for the mosquito population in arid environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Aedes aegypti, the primary vector of dengue, yellow fever, chikungunya, and Zika viruses, has recently become well-established in Maricopa County, Arizona and the broader southwestern United States. Recently identified cases of locally-acquired dengue fever have sparked concern about viruses transmitted by Ae. aegypti being imported to Maricopa County, an area with over 4.5 million residents, most of whom are naïve to viruses transmitted by this mosquito. Our study contributes to the growing body of literature on the phylogenetic structure of Ae. Aegypti populations by providing the first collection of 94 mitochondrial genome sequences from the Maricopa County, Arizona population of the mosquito after its recent population expansion in this region. We are in the process of submitting these genomes to Genbank. We employed phylogeographic techniques to investigate the spatial distribution and movement of the mosquito vector of interest in Maricopa County.
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Aedes aegypti has historically been thought to have a very small range (about 100-200m), so we expected to find a strong relationship between sampling location and genetic similarity. Surprisingly, no distinct clades related to geographic location were identified, and we found no relationship between geographic distance and genetic distance.
BROADER IMPACTS: Our findings suggest that Aedes aegypti population mixture exists throughout the county regardless of geographic distance which has implications for vector control and public health practice in this region. Importantly, this is the first study of its kind in this region, so additional resolution may be achieved as additional samples are sequenced.


Last Modified: 11/18/2024
Modified by: Crystal M Hepp

Images (1 of )
  • Location of 30 traps from which Aedes aegypti mitochondrial genome samples were sequenced. Base map and data from OpenStreetMap and OpenStreetMap Foundation (CC-BY-SA). � https://www.openstreetmap.org and contributors.
    Whitney Holeva-Eklund
    Copyrighted
    Crystal M Hepp
    30 trap sites that Aedes aegypti were collected at
  • Ten equally parsimonious trees were created, and the bootstrap consensus tree shows all clusters supported by at least 5 of the 10 equally parsimonious trees. All samples were genetically similar indicating a mixture of populations throughout Maricopa County regardless of geographic distance.
    Whitney Holeva-Eklund
    Copyrighted
    Crystal M Hepp
    . Bootstrap consensus phylogenetic tree showing the relationship between 94 Aedes aegypti mitochondrial genomes from May-November 2020 in Maricopa County, AZ
  • No clear relationship is present indicating that there is a mixture of populations in Maricopa County, AZ regardless of distance.
    Whitney Holeva-Eklund
    Copyrighted
    Crystal M Hepp
    Plot of geographic distance against proportional genetic distance
